channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Investigators Call Evidence in the Ahmaud Arbery Shooting ‘Extremely Upsetting’
item.description: A father and son were arrested in connection with the Feb. 23 killing of Mr. Arbery, which had led to protests and 2.23-mile runs to show support under the hashtag #IRunWithMaud.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Sarah Mervosh and Richard Fausset
item.media:description: A rally in Brunswick, Ga., on Friday to protest the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: Back in Session, State Legislatures Challenge Governors’ Authority
item.description: Mayors, governors and President Trump have been the main players in disputes over how to reopen states and cities. But now state lawmakers are leaping into the fray.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: State representatives in Jackson, Miss., last week. The state has been gripped by an intramural fight between the Republican governor, Tate Reeves, and the Republican-led Legislature.

item.title: Coronavirus and Reopening: As Governors Urge Caution, G.O.P. Lawmakers Rebel
item.description: The intraparty warfare in Ohio is part of a growing rebellion by Republicans who say closures are smothering the economy and violating rights.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabriella Caldwell prepared a flower shop for reopening in Columbus, Ohio, on Thursday. Retail stores in the state will be able to reopen later this month.

item.title: Indianapolis Police Fatally Shoot Man Who May Have Streamed Encounter on Facebook Live
item.description: The police said the man was killed after shooting at an officer who chased him for driving recklessly. The man apparently recorded a video several minutes long during the pursuit.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Indianapolis residents gathered at the scene of a shooting on Wednesday.

item.title: For a Georgia Police Force, a Bungled Shooting Case Follows a Trail of Woes
item.description: The shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery has renewed criticism of the police agency that released the two suspects. They were charged by the state months later.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Richard Fausset and Serge F. Kovaleski
item.media:description: A cross near the Georgia neighborhood where Ahmaud Arbery, a black man, was fatally shot in February after being chased by a white former police officer and his son.

item.title: A Drug Cocktail Hastens Recovery in Some Coronavirus Patients
item.description: A combination of three antiviral drugs, including interferon, seemed to speed recovery, researchers reported.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients with Covid-19 hospitalized in Argentina. In a new study, those receiving a triple-drug treatment in Hong Kong improved more quickly than those in a comparison group, researchers reported on Friday.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Video Was Leaked by a Lawyer Who Consulted With Suspects
item.description: The lawyer, Alan Tucker, declined to comment on his conversations with the suspects, citing attorney-client privilege. He later said he would not be representing them.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: Demonstrators holding signs Friday at a memorial for Ahmaud Arbery in Brunswick, Ga., near where he was shot and killed in February.

item.title: Chief Justice Roberts Rejects Request for Inquiry into D.C. Appeals Court Vacancy
item.description: The top circuit court judge had asked the complaint be transferred and investigated, but the chief justice’s office said it did not qualify.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Judge Justin Walker is sworn in prior to testifying before a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Walker's nomination to be a U.S. circuit judge for the District of Columbia Circuit on Capitol Hill in Washington, Wednesday.

item.title: Dropping of Michael Flynn Case Heightens Fear of Justice Dept. Politicization
item.description: Across the country, rank-and-file prosecutors cringed at another extraordinary intervention by Attorney General William P. Barr.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr has consistently sided with President Trump on politically-tinged issues.

item.title: Overlooked No More: June Almeida, Scientist Who Identified the First Coronavirus
item.description: In 1966, she used a powerful electron microscope to capture an image of a mysterious pathogen — the first coronavirus known to cause human disease.
item.dc:creator: Denise Gellene
item.media:credit: Norman James/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: June Almeida in 1963 at the Ontario Cancer Institute in Toronto. In her day she gained a reputation for “extending the range of the electron microscope to new limits.”

item.title: In Michael Flynn Case, William Barr Again Takes Aim at Robert Mueller Inquiry
item.description: The Justice Department’s move was the latest example of the attorney general’s effort to chisel away at the special counsel investigation and emphasize an alternate narrative.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: The investigation by Robert S. Mueller III revealed a historic campaign by Russia to sabotage the 2016 presidential election.

item.title: Tesla Tells Workers It Will Reopen California Factory Despite County Order
item.description: The electric car company told employees to report to work Friday, but a county official said Tesla did not meet the requirements for resuming production.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Tesla’s factory in Fremont, Calif., in March. It has been closed since March 23.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Shooting: A Timeline of the Case
item.description: A look at the major moments between Mr. Arbery’s killing in a Georgia suburb and the arrest of two suspects, both charged with murder.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Brunswick, Ga., on Friday to protest the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: Haphazard Rollout of Coronavirus Drug Frustrates Doctors
item.description: Remdesivir was shipped to small hospitals even as besieged medical centers were denied access.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:credit: Stan Grossfeld/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston in March. Though other major hospitals did not receive supplies of remdesivir, Mass General did — without asking. “We have no idea how this landed with us,” said one doctor.

item.title: Michael Pack: Trump Pushes for Senate to Confirm Conservative to Run Voice of America
item.description: A key Senate committee has scheduled a vote on the long-stalled nomination of Michael Pack, an ally of Stephen K. Bannon, to run the agency in charge of the Voice of America. Employees are worried.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for Global Media
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Voice of America studio in Washington. Voice of America is the largest American international broadcaster.

item.title: On Ahmaud Arbery’s Birthday, Thousands Say #IRunWithMaud
item.description: People documented their 2.23-mile runs on Friday using the hashtag to show solidarity with Mr. Arbery, who was killed on Feb. 23.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: A solidarity badge displayed during the rally.

item.title: When Will Companies Let Workers Back Into the Office
item.description: Google, Facebook, Amazon, Capital One and others are extending work-from-home policies to September and sometimes far beyond.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Stuart Isett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rich Barton, Zillow chief executive, tweeted his support for working from home last month.

item.title: Travel Reopenings Amid the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: As Australia announces plans to revive tourism, we look at 10 top travel destinations and their timetables for reopening. The challenge: balancing safety with the need to reboot.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sloss
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Amalfi coast in Italy. The country, devastated by Covid-19, is starting to think about how to open up to tourism.

item.title: Coronavirus in Florida: Grim Medical Records Recount Lonely Deaths
item.description: Records kept by medical examiners in Florida offer a window into how the coronavirus has killed more than 1,600 people there. Many died at home.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Rebecca Halleck and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Dirk Shadd/Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A patient is transported by ambulance from the Freedom Square Seminole Nursing Pavilion in Seminole, Fla., last month. More than a third of Floridians killed by the coronavirus lived in a nursing home or other long-term care facility.

item.title: Oh, Good, the Kids Are Fighting Again
item.description: Nobody said listening to kids bicker is fun. But lockdown offers a chance to teach them how to resolve conflicts on their own.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Ian Whitcomb, Rocker Turned Pop Music Historian, Dies at 78
item.description: After his 1965 single “You Turn Me On” became a Top 10 hit, he renounced rock stardom for older musical idioms like ragtime.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: Trump Praises Barr and Revels in Dismissal of Charges Against Flynn
item.description: In a Fox News interview, Mr. Trump also angrily revived grievances about the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III and promised a swift economic rebound.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Trump praised Attorney General William P. Barr for dropping the case against Michael T. Flynn.

item.title: アメリカに「殺人バチ」が上陸 オオスズメバチを阻止せよ
item.description: オオスズメバチの目撃情報 アメリカに定着すればミツバチの生息数に壊滅的被害をもたらす可能性
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: ルス・フレムソン/ニューヨークタイムズ
item.media:description: 「オオスズメバチを定着させるかどうか、今が瀬戸際だ」ワシントン州農務省の昆虫学者クリス・ルーニー氏は上着の上で体長2インチのオオスズメバチの死骸を見せてくれた。

item.title: F.D.A. Clears First Home Saliva Test for Coronavirus
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration is permitting a Rutgers lab to start selling spit-collection kits to detect the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Kaplan and Natasha Singer
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
item.media:description: Dr. Stephen Hahn, the F.D.A. commissioner, speaking at the White House last month. He said the Rutgers test kit “combines the ease of saliva collection with at-home collection.”

item.title: In Court Document, Tara Reade’s Ex-Husband Said She Spoke of Harassment
item.description: Ms. Reade’s former husband said she spoke of a sexual harassment problem she had when working in Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s Senate office. Mr. Biden has denied her allegation of sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tara Reade was an aide in the Senate office of Joseph R. Biden Jr. in the early 1990s.

item.title: U.S. Leads the World’s Virus Fight? That’s News to the World
item.description: The State Department insists the Trump administration is at the fore of the global response to the coronavirus, but worries persist about an American retrenchment.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Test kits to detect the coronavirus being donated to Honduras last month. A diplomatic withdrawal may also include cutting ties with the W.H.O. when the administration concludes a review this summer.

item.title: How Coronavirus Is Taking a Toll on Mental Health
item.description: As quarantine drags on, two journalists have an honest conversation about the hard-to-ignore rising levels of stress.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Donner and Corinne Purtill

item.title: Newsom Reopens Some Businesses in California
item.description: Friday: It’s a modest step in a brighter direction, but a huge budget deficit looms. Also: A remembrance, and walks.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A man walking his dog Tuesday night in the Van Nuys section of Los Angeles.

item.title: Authorities Investigate Death on Austin Runway Where Southwest Flight Landed
item.description: Flight 1392 landed at Austin-Bergstrom International Airport on Thursday night and tried to avoid a collision, the airline said. Medical teams said the person died at the scene.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A Southwest Airlines flight on the tarmac in Austin, Texas, in 2019.

item.title: The Government Is Ready to Reopen. Its Citizens Aren’t, Polls Show.
item.description: Americans remain wary of the coronavirus’s threat, and are worried about going back to work too soon. But that doesn’t mean they’re not hurting.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Coronavirus, Ahmaud Arbery, Michael Flynn: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Outside a bar in Vilnius, Lithuania.

item.title: Coronavirus Live News and Updates
item.description: All California voters will receive mail-in ballots for the November election. President Trump will be tested daily for the coronavirus after a valet fell ill.

item.title: 2020 Republican National Convention in North Carolina: Full Steam Ahead for Trump?
item.description: The president craves a nationally televised coronation with cheering supporters, but even Republican lawmakers in North Carolina are expressing doubts it can take place as planned.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrations after Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican Party’s nomination at its convention in Cleveland in 2016. He would like a similar packed arena this year.

item.title: Paid Leave Law Tries to Help Millions in Crisis. Many Haven’t Heard of It.
item.description: The program has received relatively little publicity, and there has been confusion among business owners and workers.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: With schools and day care centers shuttered, working parents have struggled. But a new paid leave program created to help them is not well known and has been little used.

item.title: U.S. Jobs Report Shows Clearest Data Yet on Economic Toll: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus World News: Live Updates
item.description: India has started a major operation to repatriate its people. In Kenya, people held in quarantine for weeks were forced to pay to be released.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A chapel at the Xilotepec cemetery in Mexico City was sterilized on Thursday.

item.title: G.O.P. Coronavirus Message: Economic Crisis Is a Green New Deal Preview
item.description: As the economy melts down, embattled conservatives are testing a political response: saying Democratic climate policies would bring similar pain.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A section of freeway in Pasadena, Calif., in late April.

item.title: New York Man Charged With Fraud Over Coronavirus Home Tests
item.description: Henry Gindt II, 34, shipped stolen test kits to several customers, who never received the results despite spending as much as $200 per test, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: “The Department of Justice will take swift action to disrupt your scheme, and then we will arrest you,” an official said of virus-related fraud.

item.title: ‘Never Seen Anything Like This’: Experts Question Dropping of Flynn Prosecution
item.description: Abandoning the case is the latest step in a pattern of dismantling the work of the Russia investigators. A former prosecutor likened it to eating the department from the inside out.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The case against Michael T. Flynn had become a political cause for President Trump and his supporters.
